content: Dr. Imed Zaguia Skip to main content Skip to "About this site" Dr. Imed Zaguia Dr. Imed Zaguia Full Professor and Associate Head of the Department Office: Girouard Building, room 302 Telephone: (613) 541-6000 ext. 6078 Fax: (613) 541-6584 E-mail: zaguia@rmc.ca Department of Mathematics and Computer Science College Address Royal Military College of CanadaPO Box 17000, Station ForcesKingston, Ontario, CANADAK7K 7B4 Research Interests: Ordered sets Linear extensions Ordered groups Graphs Combinatorics Well-quasi-ordering Hereditary Classes Theory of Relations Short biography I am a Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science. I taught most of the undergraduate courses in Mathematics and several core courses in Computer Science. My research interests broadly lie in the study of combinatorial and relational structures. One of my research interests is concerned with the study of permutation classes, a very active field of research motivated by the Stanly–Wilf Conjecture, solved in 2004 by Marcus and Tardos. Permutations appear in the study of bichains, permutation graphs and more generally in the study of relational structures. Problems studied in this area include the study of hereditary classes of permutations and their growth functions. I am especially investigating the question of well-quasi-ordering in combinatorial objects and the corresponding construction of infinite antichains. I also investigate the structure of ordered groups. These are groups that are endowed with a compatible partial order relation. I study the interaction the interactions between order and group operation in an ordered group I am also working on a central conjecture related to linear extensions of partially ordered sets: The 1/3-2/3 Conjecture (1968, unsolved). The conjecture states that, if one is comparison sorting a set of objects then, no matter what comparisons may have already been performed; it is always possible to choose the next comparison in such a way that it will reduce the number of possible sorted orders by a factor of 2/3 or better. This problem was listed as a featured unsolved problem in the founding volume of the journal Order, a journal on the Theory of Ordered Sets and its Applications. Selected Publications: M.
